dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Informative and analytical discussion about economics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: US corporations have benefited for decades from globalization's deflationary effects, but that era seems to be ending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: U S corporations have benefited for decades from globalization's deflationary effects, but that era seems to be ending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For decades, US corporations have benefited tremendously from globalizations deflationary effects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's really those supply-chain constraints from China's zero-COVID policy and the war in Ukraine that are driving up prices now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's really those supply-chain constraints from China's zero-COVID policy and the war in Ukraine that are driving up prices now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, however, ongoing supply-chain constraints related to Chinas strict zero-COVID policy and Russias war in Ukraine are expected to continue to raise the prices of food, fuel, and manufactured goods over the short and medium term.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the Wharton School study found over 950 companies, many American, have scaled back in Russia beyond just sanctions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the Wharton School study found over nine hundred fifty companies, many American, have scaled back in Russia beyond just sanctions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the Yale School of Managements tracker, more than 1,000 companies many of them American have voluntarily curtailed their Russian operations beyond what international sanctions require.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is part of this bigger trend—companies are prioritizing resilience over low costs, leading to massive capital repatriation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is part of this bigger trend-companies are prioritizing resilience over low costs, leading to massive capital repatriation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As interest rates rise and supply chains remain vulnerable, US companies are favoring resilience over low production costs, leading to massive capital repatriation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that means more dollars chasing US assets, which puts even more upward pressure on prices here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that means more dollars chasing U S assets, which puts even more upward pressure on prices here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a deglobalizing economy, more investment capital would flow back to the US, leading to a higher volume of dollars chasing US assets and putting more upward pressure on prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Core goods inflation jumped from under 1.8% in early 2021 to 6.2% by mid-2022. That's a huge spike.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Core goods inflation jumped from under one point eight percent in early twenty twenty one to six point two percent by midminus twenty twenty two. That's a huge spike.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is no surprise, then, that core goods inflation in the United States has increased sharply, from less than 2% at the start of 2021 to 6% in mid-2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And unlike 2008, there's no coordinated monetary response among major economies this time around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And unlike two thousand eight, there's no coordinated monetary response among major economies this time around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike the coordinated monetary response to the 2008 global financial crisis, policymakers in the worlds major economies seem to believe that every country must fend for itself in the fight against todays inflationary surge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Every country's just fending for itself, which honestly might be making things worse globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Every country's just fending for itself, which honestly might be making things worse globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The absence of global cooperation hurts many of the worlds most vulnerable countries the most.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially for vulnerable countries—when the Fed hikes rates, the dollar strengthens, and they face higher import-led inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially for vulnerable countries-when the Fed hikes rates, the dollar strengthens, and they face higher import-led inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When major central banks hike interest rates, they export inflation to smaller countries. Aggressive monetary tightening in the US has already led the dollar to rise against the pound, breach parity with the euro, and reach a 20-year high against the yen, propelling higher import-led inflation in countries whose currencies have weakened.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like we're exporting inflation to smaller economies, which is pretty concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like we're exporting inflation to smaller economies, which is pretty concerning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When major central banks hike interest rates, they export inflation to smaller countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got these tit-for-tat trade barriers, like between the US and China, further fragmenting things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got these tit-for-tat trade barriers, like between the U S and China, further fragmenting things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conversely, diplomatic fragmentation a defining characteristic of our current age of deglobalization increases the likelihood of tit-for-tat measures, which have led to the erection of multiple trade barriers in recent years, most notably between the US and China and between the United Kingdom and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So even if the Fed's rate hikes curb demand, policymakers still need to address the structural shifts from deglobalization.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even if the Fed's rate hikes curb demand, policymakers still need to address the structural shifts from deglobalization.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Feds current efforts to stamp out inflation by hiking interest rates and shrinking its balance sheet will reduce demand and thus help curb price growth. But policymakers must also devise measures that mitigate the impact of todays deglobalizing world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Dambisa Moyo, the economist cited here, argues that without coordination, these pressures are just keep building.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dambisa Moyo, the economist cited here, argues that without coordination, these pressures are just keep building.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tackling inflation in the US and globally requires a coordinated multilateral response. Taken together, these trends herald a global environment that will continue to fuel higher US inflation, even if America is less vulnerable than other advanced economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like we're entering a whole new economic era, and it's not exactly a smooth transition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like we're entering a whole new economic era, and it's not exactly a smooth transition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Resilience might be the new priority, but it comes at a cost—higher prices for everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Resilience might be the new priority, but it comes at a cost-higher prices for everyone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But deglobalization will likely contribute to inflationary pressures by increasing companies operating costs, thereby keeping US inflation higher than the 1-2% range recorded over most of the past decade and hovering near the Feds 2% target rate.

artist_script:
At a time of rising inflation and fractured global supply chains...
HostA: US corporations have benefited for decades from globalization's deflationary effects, but that era seems to be ending.
HostB: Yeah, and it's really those supply-chain constraints from China's zero-COVID policy and the war in Ukraine that are driving up prices now.
HostA: Exactly. And the Wharton School study found over 950 companies, many American, have scaled back in Russia beyond just sanctions.
HostB: Which is part of this bigger trend—companies are prioritizing resilience over low costs, leading to massive capital repatriation.
HostA: Right, and that means more dollars chasing US assets, which puts even more upward pressure on prices here.
HostB: Core goods inflation jumped from under 1.8% in early 2021 to 6.2% by mid-2022. That’s a huge spike.
HostA: And unlike 2008, there's no coordinated monetary response among major economies this time around.
HostB: Every country's just fending for itself, which honestly might be making things worse globally.
HostA: Especially for vulnerable countries—when the Fed hikes rates, the dollar strengthens, and they face higher import-led inflation.
HostB: It’s like we're exporting inflation to smaller economies, which is pretty concerning.
HostA: And then you've got these tit-for-tat trade barriers, like between the US and China, further fragmenting things.
HostB: So even if the Fed’s rate hikes curb demand, policymakers still need to address the structural shifts from deglobalization.
HostA: Dambisa Moyo, the economist cited here, argues that without coordination, these pressures are just keep building.
HostB: It feels like we're entering a whole new economic era, and it’s not exactly a smooth transition.
HostA: Definitely. Resilience might be the new priority, but it comes at a cost—higher prices for everyone.
